questions.question_text:
A retail company runs their online shopping platform entirely on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). This is a 3-tier web application that includes a 100 Mbps Load
Balancer, Virtual Machine Instances for web and application tiers, and an Oracle DB Systems Virtual Machine. Due to unprecedented growth, they noticed an increase in the incoming traffic to their website and all users start getting 503 (Service Unavailable) errors.
What is the potential problem in this scenario? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content: Answer is E: A 503 Service Unavailable Error is an HTTP response status code indicating that a server is temporarily unable to handle the request. This may be due to the server being overloaded or down for maintenance.
in today exam

Correct answer is E. A is wrong totally. B is wrong as well because this is just happen in the peak time. C means just a half of backend servers is in critical situation means still have a half to serve the request. D is wrong because if database is down, you will see a total different kind of error (500 for example) but this is 503 mean the request has not been served.

Selected Answer: E
E. All the web servers are too busy and not able to answer any request from users.
The server must be overloaded or down for maintenance.
E for sure
E is most probable in this case. D also could be a reason.
Answer is E.
B is not right, because this is not DNS traffic problem.

Answer E: 503 is an error, comes when server being overloaded. Read https://medium.com/tensult/troubleshooting-http-503-errors-returned-when-using-a-classic-load-balancer-c11d58da3595#:~:text=The%20most%20common%20reason%20for,instances%20are%20failing%20health%20checks.
why not B?
should be B

choices.A: You did not configure a Service Gateway to allow connection between web servers and Load Balancer.
choices.E: All the web servers are too busy and not able to answer any request from users.
choices.C: The Load Balancer health check status indicates critical situation for half of the backend web servers.
choices.D: The Database is down hence users cannot access the web site.
choices.B: The Traffic Management Policy is not set to Load Balancer the traffic to the web servers.

questions.question_text:
An automobile company wants to deploy their CRM application for Oracle Database on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) DB Systems for one of its major clients.
In compliance with the business continuity program of the client, they need to provide a Recovery Point Objective (RPO) of 24 hours and a Recovery Time
Objective (RTO) of 1 hour. The CRM application should be available even in the event that an entire OCI Region is down.
Which approach meets these requirements in the most cost effective manner? (Choose the best answer.)

choices.C: Deploy an Autonomous Transaction Processing database in one region and replicate it to an Autonomous Transaction Processing database in another region using Oracle GoldenGate.
choices.D: Deploy a 2 node Virtual Machine (VM) Oracle RAC database in one region and replicate the database to a 2 node VM Oracle RAC database in another region using a manual setup and configuration of Oracle Data Guard.
choices.B: Deploy a 1 node VM Oracle database in one region and replicate the database to a 1 node VM Oracle database in another region using a manual setup and configuration of Oracle Data Guard.
choices.A: Deploy a 1 node VM Oracle database in one region. Manually Configure a Recovery Manager (RMAN) database backup schedule to take hourly database backups. Asynchronously copy the database backups to object storage in another OCI region. If the primary OCI region is unavailable, launch a new 1 node VM Database in the other OCI region and restore the production database from the backup.

discussion.content: B is the answer: RAC Database is not required in this solution. Standalone will be most suitable and cost effective. You can create the standby DB system in a different availability domain from the primary DB system for availability and disaster recovery purposes. With Data Guard and switchover/failover can meet RTO 1 hour.

Selected Answer: B
A. Hard to do a recovery in 1 hour (RTO)
B. Data Guard is included in EE and you achieve RTO of 1 hour. You can achieve goals and is more cost-effective than with RAC.
C. Makes no sense
D. Is more expensive and you need Extreme Performance for RAC
Why not A? It is even more cost effective? The only cons is if you are able to recover RMAN backup in 1 hour, but the size of the DB is not specified in the question.

Selected Answer: D
Similar at the
B should be the answer because of its acos effective solution. even though D is abtter solution for a larger company

B looks good, but please consider that this is a major client of this company, and the business continuity is critical, even in case of entirely region down, that rarely happen with the cloud computing. So that, a design for this kind of company and requirement is not just based on the cost aspect. A single node of database is quite risk even you can switch back and forth. A RAC solution is more resonable in this case, so D is the most applicable option. --> D is correct answer.
ATP cannot be source for goldengate to replicate,so C not right choice, B is right one
Why not C?

comments.content: I think C is not very cheap to run comparing to A,B.

discussion.content: B is correct
in todays exam

Selected Answer: E
data.identity.principalId

Selected Answer: E
The answer is E Specifically "data.identity.principalId"
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Audit/Reference/logeventreference.htm

The answer is E. principalId: OCID of the requestor
Reference:
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Logging/Reference/details_for_object_storage.htm

why not requestOrigin?
have the ip adrees

comments.content: What is the request is coming from an application running on a Terminal Server/RDS, Citrix server, Xen Server or something like that. All of the users on the server would have the same IP. The IP address only tells you the hardware that the reque3st came from, not the person on the hardware that initiated the request. OCIDs are unique forever, IPs come and go and get reused like bathroom door handles.

discussion.content: E is correct
the answer is correct
E is right
Correct: data.identity.principalId The OCID of the principal.

A&B: Autonomous Database is an Oracle Managed and Secure environment.
A physical database can’t simply be migrated to autonomous because:
- Database must be converted to PDB, upgraded to 19c, and encrypted
- Any changes to Oracle shipped privileges, stored procedures or views must be removed - All legacy structures and unsupported features must be removed (e.g. legacy LOBs) GoldenGate replication can be used to keep database online during migration
should be AB
A&B is the right one. See: https://www.oracle.com/a/ocom/docs/autonomous-db-l200.pdf

Selected Answer: AB
Autonomous Database is an Oracle Managed and Secure environment.
A physical database can't simply be migrated to autonomous because:
- Database must be converted to PDB, upgraded to 19c, and encrypted
- Any changes to Oracle shipped privileges, stored procedures or views must be removed
- All legacy structures and unsupported features must be removed (e.g. legacy LOBs) GoldenGate replication can be used to keep database online during migration

Selected Answer: AB
How to think: you must convert due to the versions,, so B is mandatory, D and E are ruled out.
Then you must decide if Data Guard or Goldengate would do the trick
A & B are correct as this is included in the official Oracle Training Practice Test.

Selected Answer: AB
Ans is AB, confirmed with OCI training exam.
A&B are correct
A&B are correct

Correct Is 
A-B
AB is the answer

choices.C: Use Oracle Data Guard to keep on-premises database always active during migration.
choices.A: Use Oracle GoldenGate replication to keep on-premises database online during migration.
choices.D: Retain changes to Oracle shipped privileges, stored procedures or views in the on-premises databases.
choices.B: Convert on-premises databases to PDB, upgrade to 19c, and encrypt.
choices.E: Retain all legacy structures and unsupported features (e.g. legacy LOBs) in the on-premises databases for migration.

questions.question_text:
You are responsible for migrating your on-premises legacy databases on 11.2.0.4 version to Autonomous Transaction Processing "" Dedicated (ATP""D) in Oracle
Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). As a solution architect, you need to plan your migration approach.
Which two options do you need to implement together to migrate your on-premises databases to OCI? (Choose two.)

An online stock trading application is deployed to multiple Availability Domains in the us-phoenix-1 region. Considering the high volume of financial transactions that the trading application handles, the company has hired you to ensure that the data stored by the application is scalable, highly-available, and disaster resilient.
In the event of failure, the Recovery Time Objective (RTO) must be less than 2 hours to meet regulatory compliance requirements.
Which Disaster Recovery strategy should be used to achieve the RTO requirement in the event of system failure? (Choose the best answer.)

discussion.content: should be D
D is the answer: You can use the CLI, REST APIs, or the SDKs to automate, script, and manage volume backups and their lifecycle.

Selected Answer: D
You can use the CLI, REST APIs, or the SDKs to automate, script, and manage volume backups and their lifecycle.
Planning Your Backup
The primary use of backups is to support business continuity, disaster recovery, and long-term archiving requirements. When determining a backup schedule, your backup plan and goals should consider the following:
Frequency: How often you want to back up your data.
Recovery time: How long you can wait for a backup to be restored and accessible to the applications that use it. The time for a backup to complete varies on several factors, but it will generally take a few minutes or longer, depending on the size of the data being backed up and the amount of data that has changed since your last backup.
Number of stored backups: How many backups you need to keep available and the deletion schedule for those you no longer need. You can only create one backup at a time, so if a backup is underway, it will need to complete before you can create another one. For details about the number of backups you can store

Selected Answer: D
Per official exam
Correct answer is D as this is included in the official Oracle Practice Test

why not B?

comments.content:
A: Wrong, you try going to your product development team and tell them to rewrite the application to support 'synchronous master-slave data replication'. You'll get laughed all the way back to your Window(s). 
B: Storage Gateway is not a real thing.
C: Anit nobody brought up NVMe in the first place, "What you talking about Willis?"
D: A viable solution.

discussion.content: A: While storage snapshots are widely used to quickly create point-in-time virtual copies of data, they are also often marketed as valid “backup solutions”. This is an incorrect and dangerous assumption because snapshots, unless copied to secondary media (e.g. another storage array or tape), do not protect against media failures. While there are benefits of using snapshots for development or testing purposes on non-production systems, they should not be considered as valid data protection or backups of Oracle databases. Instead, customers should look to Recovery Manager (RMAN) and Fast Recovery Area (FRA) as the Oracle-supported solution to create and manage Oracle database backups. Note that since RMAN and Fast Recovery Area are built-in features of the Oracle database, this solution also applies to Oracle Exadata Database Machine, with the additional benefit of extremely high performance.

Answer is A. The Storage backup are not data backup, you must plan data replication across AD. Volume backups are not considered as data . https://www.oracle.com/database/technologies/rman-fra-snapshot.html

choices.C: Store hourly block volumes backup to NVME device under a compute instance and generate a custom image every 5 minutes.
choices.A: Configure your application to use synchronous master-slave data replication between Availability Domains.
choices.D: Configure hourly block volumes backups using the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Command Line Interface (CLI).
choices.B: Configure hourly block volumes backups through the Storage Gateway service.
